Niesamowita gra 9.5/10 :)Plusy:+ Kilka zakończeń+ Wciągająca fabuła+ Długość rozgrywki+ Dodatek Droga do Gehenny+ Muzyka, projekt etapów, grafika+ Satysfakcjonujące zagadki logiczne+ Wybory natury filozoficzno-egzystencjonalnej

Portal + SOMA = The Talos PrincipleВ далеком  2007 году на свет вышел Portal, который мгновенное получил хвалебные отзывы критиков за идеальное сочетание идеи, свежей подачи и интересных головоломок, а главное завоевал любовь фанатов. Спустя 4 года вышла вторая часть, как продолжение - хорошо, но выше головы не прыгнуло. 2015 года в продажу поступил "Принцип Талоса" от Croteam. Удивительно, но эти ребятки создали хороший шутан Serious Sam, в котором вопросов о вечном не ставилось, только кровь, кишки и орды противников. Самое замечательное, что в Талосе разработчики смогли пойти другим путем, а не стали копировать сами себя.Гениальное сочетание Portal и SOMA. Обе игры нашли свое отражение в "Принципе Талоса". Но начнем по порядку. PortalСюжеты Portal и The Talos Principle сильно разняться, но от этого их схожесть остается явной: голос, что после пробуждения говорит тебе, что нужно делать, загадки, кубы... Правда в Талосе и предметов побольше и загадки порой адовые (в прохождение придется часто заглядывать ^_^) The Talos Principle сильно подтянул сюжетную составляющую Portal, что несомненно стало его сильной стороной. SOMAДабы не проспойлерить, скажу одно, что основная мысль и решение судьбы человечества в  Соме и Талосе схожи. В чем же разница? В SOMA только в самом конце ты понимаешь всю глубину замысла разработчиков. Талос же в течение всей игры держит в напряжении, заставляет задумать: Для чего ты живешь? Куда ты идешь? Что значит быть человеком? Этому в первую очередь способствуют тексты, которые протагонист находит на компьютерах - там и личная переписка, и просто чаты, блоги, древние тексты перекликающиеся с происходящим. Это позволяет погрузиться в атмосферу удивительной вселенной, то чего так не хватило в Соме. Возможно мне показалось, но есть некоторые отсылки к игре SOMA от Frictional Games, ибо проект, о котором идет речь во вселенной The Talos Principle первоначально хотели назвать "СОМА", но в итоге остановились на "СОМА/ТАЛОС"Звуковое сопровождениеОсобенно хотелось отметить замечательную вещь как "капсулы времени", то как великолепно ее озвучили на русском языке, сам текст, пробирающий до мурашек. И самое важное - осознание того, что наша жизнь настолько коротка, так быстротечна...Музыкальное сопровождение великолепное на протяжение всей игры. ГрафикаПервый уровень я просто ходила и рассматривала все вокруг: трава, деревья, голубого неба. Ошеломляющее ощущение погружения, которое я совершенно не ожидала. Конечно, для тех, кто хочет увидеть картинку как в Dark Souls 3, то ожидать этого вряд ли стоит. Кому советовать? Не советовала бы любителям экшена.  The Talos Principle размеренная, философская, созерцательная. Над некоторыми загадками придется просидеть не один десяток минут. Да и читать постоянно тексты многим современным игрокам вряд ли по душе. ВЕРДИКТЭто идеальная игра для тех, кто ищет не просто развлечения для убийства времени, но и готов расшевелить мозги. Огромное спасибо, что дочитали обзор до конца ( ･｡･) ˜ ♡Если хочешь посмотреть, как я прохожу игры, подписывайся на мой канал YouTube

Шедевральная игра, для любителей головоломок просто обязательна к наличию в библиотеке. Играя в неё есть такое чувство, будто бы сама по себе эта игра это что-то важное, больше чем просто посидеть за компом вечером после работы или в выходной. Тут и почитать есть что и подумать и загадки порешать.

I'm not going to fawn all over this piece like the other positive reviews.  I hate puzzle games, and I hate indie games.  I only got about 75% of the way through this one.  But I like the Talos Principle.  The game has a few problems, but I still recommend it at 20 dollars or below if you're a puzzle fan.  The graphics have an eerie beauty, along with pretty good sound design.  Optimization is pretty iffy.  I destroy this game's recommended specs, but I could NOT get a good framerate without certain graphical options looking pretty bad.  The backstory of the game is nonsense, biologically speaking, but it more than serves its purpose here.  Meanwhile, at the forefront, you awaken as a robot in what quickly reveals itself to be a simulation of some kind designed to develop your programming.  Your only companions are a big booming Judeo-Christian god voice from everywhere, recordings of the simulation designers, and a sarcastic, unfunny computer AI that likes to ask you philosophical questions.  Story fragments exist on terminals in the form of western or middle-eastern ideological pieces, and emails between the humans who designed the system.  Personally, I find it hard to believe that a bunch of genius computer scientists would have designed such a simple simulation to train a true A.I. The puzzles exist in a half dozen chambers for each world, with seven worlds for each temple, in a total of three temples, for the most part.  There are some tertiary puzzles to solve of the same types if you want one of the game's different endings.  As you acquire more Tetris pieces, you unlock more components to solve puzzles with.  These are usually things like pylons to redirect energy beams, boxes to stand on, and so forth.  By far the coolest one is a recording device that records yourself and everything you interact with, and after you play it back you can then interact with your other fictional self to complete otherwise impossible tasks.  However, every one of these tools, with the exception of that one, are "abilities" that should have been unlocked at the beginning of the game, not major features of it.  Most puzzles resolve themselves pretty quickly, but by the second temple the "samey-ness" some people describe feeling has fully taken root, and the game becomes fully repetitive and tedious.  Some of this has to do with the plodding pace at which the story is delivered, but for myself, I couldn't get past a singular realization: there is only ONE puzzle in this game.  This theme is, to use the technical industry phrase, "Not enough stuff."  Every single puzzle in the game would resolve itself in under a minute if you had one, maybe two more of something.  One more box.  One more jammer.  One more pylon.  You can literally go into any puzzle area and ask "Okay, what did they not give me enough of?"  and you will thematically already be at the puzzle's solution.  Yes, there are many puzzles, and definitely yes, there are an astounding number of variations, but only within this ONE THEME.  A bit through the third temple it felt like the game was simply gating the end of the story in an attempt to extend its lifespan.  Some object interactions by the player and collision detections are highly restricted to limit the mechanics and solutions during puzzle-solving to a few of the same iterative solutions.  I did not appreciate this.  Yes, there are sometimes multiple solutions to a puzzle, but only a few pre-designated by the devs.  There are ways of preventing players from breaking your game without unnatural restrictions.So, why do I still recommend this game after ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ all over it?   Because my complaints, though accurate, are mostly personal preference.  That makes them even arguable as to whether or not they're important to the fundamental design of the game.  I would have liked to have seen a greater variety of mechanics in the puzzles, with more solutions.  More philosophical diversity was badly needed for an older gamer like myself who has seen all of this material before.  The sometimes absurd degrees of restriction in movement and interaction with the environment limit further solutions from being possible, making the game on-rails more than I'd like.    But at the end of the day, most players will not - and would not - care about those complaints, and so Talos Principle stands as an achievement for both indie and puzzle games, and mostly deserves all of its success.
我话落这，如果打胶和塔罗斯两者只能选一个，我会把牛子剁了
我不是一个晕3d的人，但玩了这个游戏有时会莫名其妙的反胃（生理上），切身体会晕车的感觉。

This is probably my favorite first person puzzle game. Yes, I actually like this better than Portal games. The story was nice but isn't the main attraction here, the puzzles are which is as it should be. There are a lot of mechanics on display here, jammers, light prisms, time manipulation, blocks and fans. I am sure I missed a few but the point is even at its asking price, this game is good value for money. I have 15 hours in this game and it's 15 hours of puzzles, not tedious walking sim crap or unskippable cutscenes that bore you to tears, but puzzles! It is outstanding in concept and execution and has a good learning curve that doesn't throw you in the deep end but builds on increasingly complex interaction of multiple mechanics.If you are a fan of first person puzzle games or even puzzle games in general, this game is a must have in your collection.

Не знаю как описать чувства после игры в это чудо. Игра с очень сложным и философским подтекстом который будет понятен не всем и каждому. Рассуждая на такие темы как: смысл жизни, жизненные ценности, семья, вера; так же затрагивая другие насущные темы, при этом приправляя это все горой отличных размышлений через капсулы времени, компьютеры, головоломки от решения которых ты получаешь удовольствие, выстраивается некая игровая до мурашек атмосферная экосистема заставляющая думающего игрока реально задумываться (парадокс какой-то) над описанными в игре вещами. Это ли не пример идеальной игры?Конечно после этого Portal кажется детской забавой.100/100Masterpiece. Phenomenal. The one best game for me

This is simply the best puzzle game I've ever seen that isn't Portal 2.  Amazingly enough, it is obviously NOT aiming for the same target as Portal 2 anyway.  Honestly, if you like this kind of first-person, intelligent, and dare I say transcendent game design, it's hard to imagine anything similar ever touching The Talos Principle as the serious one and Portal 2 as the funny one.  I am so impressed.  I haven't played the expansion yet because I'm still working on the optional stars and sigils which, by the way, the game will let you go back and continue even if you complete an ending.Edit: I finished all the sigils and stars in the main game and found three different endings.  The puzzles got pretty hard, but all were fair except one fourth-wall-breaking one that didn't really work for me.  You can't get every achievement in one run, and the non-linear nature of the narrative means it would be a bit tricky to reload old "backups" (saves) to try to get a few others, but I worry more about seeing all content than scoring all achievements.  I'd say it was worth finishing all unnecessary puzzles.  I found lots of secrets and Easter eggs and I'm sure there are more.

Обзор на игру "The Talos Principle"  The Talos Principle - это игра от Хорватской студии Croteam, которая прославилась серией игр "Serious Sam". Эта компания всегда занималась мясными шутерами, с кишками, оторванными конечностями, кровью и т.д. Вдруг выходит игра "The Talos Principle" Сразу задается вопрос, что это? Это филосовская игра, с необычным сюжетом и атмосферой. Компания, которая всегда занималась мясными и зубодробительными шутерами, вдруг выпускает спокойную и миролюбивую игру? Этот факт навел на меня ооочень большое любопытство. Я начал активно следить за игрой, смотреть трейлеры и т.д. И вот настал момент, когда я её купил. Как только я появился в этом мире, меня охватило чувство таинственности. Кто я? Робот? Какого черта я робот?! Что за голос говорит со мной с небес? Что мне нужно делать? Именна эта особенность, делает атмосферу этой игры незабываемой! Всю игру нам предстоит не только тупо решать головоломки, но и следовать филосовскому сюжету и смыслу. А филосовские тексты в данной игре, могут даже дать пару жизненных уроков и поводов для размышления. Даже головоломки несут в себе смысл в этой игре. Играя в неё, вы одновременно думаете и наслаждаетесь этой игрой. Даже если вы не особый любитель философии, здесь вы все равно найдете потрясающе интересные головоломки, красочные и живописные виды (я их заскриншотил и поставил на рабочий стол), великолепное музыкальное сопровождение и удовольствие от прохождения! Это нечто больше чем игра...Оценки особенностей игры:[Графика: 8.5 из 10][Сюжет: 10 из 10][Музыка: 11 из 10][Дизайн уровней: 9.5 из 10] [Озвучка: 10 из 10] [Атмосфера: 12 из 10]{[]Вывод: Игра очень необычная и не похожа на другие игры, отличный филосовский сюжет, неплохая графика, интересные уровни и головоломки, великолепная музыка и незабываемая атосфера. Спасибо Croteam!!!

You must play this game if you are fan of puzzle games.What is good in The Talos Principle- Amazing soundtrack- A lot of different puzzles - Highly detailed story with philosophical background- Thousands of easter eggs waiting to be foundWhat is bad in The Talos Principle- I don't know, this game is perfect.

Я... я не могу передать то, что я увидел за 20 часов игры в этот шедевр. Но я попробую.У этой игры нет ни единого минуса.Сюжет здесь просто идеален и неповторим. Но самое удивительное, что сюжет вы усваиваете, не отвлекаясь от игрового процесса, то есть, здесь вообще нет кат-сцен (ну только 4: в начале и в конце игры(тут 3 концовки, поэтому 4 кат-сцены)).Геймплей тут очень интересный, особенно понравился сбор звезд. Тут вам придётся поднапрячь свой мозг и думать не только в пределах локации.Про графику говорить нечего, т.к. она прекрасна.Звуковое сопровождение тут великолепно. Музыка в точности передаёт атмосферу той или иной эпохи. Да-да, именно эпохи, потому что локации разбросаны в разных частях света и в разный промежуток времени.Так же ещё хочу сказать отдельно по поводу концовок. Croteam очень классно сделали возможность решать людям, как поступить в самом конце. Подняться на Башню или выбрать Вечную жизнь? Решать только вам!Итог: ну разумеется 10/10. Тут другого варианта быть не может.Отдельно хочу поблагодарить Croteam. Вы столько времени занимались разработкой зубодробительных мясных шутеров (серия игр Serious Sam если так удобней). И тут вы выдаёте такую прекрасную головоломку с философским уклоном. Это очень похвально. Просто... браво... аплодисменты. Огромное вам спасибо.

**This review does have some spoilers, but still not much from the storyline**I don't write reviews often. This game deserves one, If there was a way for me to forget the storyline completely and play this all over again, I would.This game is not just about puzzle solving, there's a very deep philosophy behind it as well. A philosophy that would make you question your existence, the universe and the human nature. What would make us different than a robot given that this robot would be able to comprehend the world as we did? The game challenges you both analytically and philosophically. I took my time reading through the archives carefully and doing assesments on the details. There are many anecdotes worth to read carefully. The timecapsules Alex has scattered around the simulation gives you goosebumps and questions our existence as species. As you move on with the game, the desperation she has can be read from her voice. Which adds a lot of feeling to the game as well.This game deserves a 10/10.

The Talos Principle ist sehr empfehlenswert für alle, die Portal mochten. Ich habe es sehr ausgiebig gespielt und habe (keine Ahnung woran es liegt) die Hauptstory sehr gut durchgespielt bekommen. Es gibt vor Allem gegen Ende einige schwierige Rätsel, die wirklich zum ausgiebigen Nachdenken auffordern. Außerdem ist der Soundtrack sehr passend und unterstützt die Stimmung im Spiel sehr passend. Die Grafik ist ebenfalls sehr gut. Nicht perfekt, d.h. es kommt nicht an Highend-Spiele wie Farcry, Battlefield oder vergleichbare (1st-Person)-Spiele heran aber ist besonders in der Darstellung der Natur und der Lichtstimmung sehr gut aufgestellt. Insgesamt also ein guter GEsamteindruck auf technischer Seite. Die Story ist nicht gerade packend und Handlungsorientiert, aber lädt dafür optimal zum nachdenken über das eigene Dasein ein (Was macht einen Mensch zu einer Person? Was bedeutet Bewusstsein? etc). Diese Denkanstöße sind jedoch nicht direkt in der "Hauptstory" des Spiels implementiert, man kann sie also auslassen. Aber es ist dennoch sehr interessant, herauszufinden, was sich auf dem "Turm", vor dem man gewarnt wird, für ein Geheimnis verbirgt und wie man eigentlich entstanden ist! Sehr spannend!Zum Gameplay noch etwas: Ich hatte während der gesamten Spielzeit das Gefühl, vollste Kontrolle über den Charakter zu haben. Das liegt vor Allem daran, dass das Spiel keine große Reaktionsgeschwindigkeit vom Spieler abverlangt und auch keine großartigen Plattformer-Elemente beinhaltet (wenn man von den Stern-Rätseln einmal absieht, aber auch diese sind leicht zu meistern). Der Fokus wird klar auf das Rätseln, nicht auf Fingerfertigkeit gelegt. Ich hätte mir lediglich gegen Ende des Spiels mehr verschiedene Rätselvariationen gewünscht... mehr benutzbare Gegenstände etc., aber dafür sorgt die Jagd nach allen Eastereggs (wovon es massig gibt) und Sternen (spezielle Sammelobjekte, welche weitere Level freischalten) für Langzeitmotivation. Alles in Allem ist das Rätseldesign sehr ansprechend und wird zunehmend komplexer. Die Lernkurve ist entsprechend moderat ansteigend. Gewisse Elemente, die man in den ersten Stunden erlernt, kommen später öfter zum Einsatz und müssen logisch verknüpft werden. Am Ende hätte ich mir jedoch nur eins gewünscht: Mehr anspruchsvolle Level außerhalb der Sternenlevel. Aber auch so gibt es mehr als genug zutun.Schlussfolgerung: The Talos Principle ist auf jeden Fall etwas für Rätsel- und Puzzlefreunde! Sprich: Kenner von Portal müssen dieses Spiel einfach kaufen! Aber auch Menschen, die eigentlich eher andere Genres zocken und Interesse haben, können sicher etwas mit dem Spiel anfangen. KLARE KAUFEMPFEHLUNG!
Portal Existential Crisis Edition.Warning: Playing may cause feelings of loneliness and insignificance in the face of nature, life, the universe and everything.42.
Купил эту игру по скидке давным давно, потому что на постере лежит красивый котик.Сыграл в неё спустя пару лет после покупки и влюбился. Мораль: всегда доверяйте котикам.

I usually don't write reviews on games but I have to say something about this game.I read a bit about it before I bought it but I never imagined a game could play mind tricks on me.It's one of those games that have a higher purpose of sort, a game that is made by a developer who thinks of games as an art form. Can a puzzle game be an art form? they sure try to make it so here.First of all the game world itself is beautifully rendered and it's pretty big, each area is big and there seems to be a lot of areas in the game - after playing only two hours and opening only 2 areas I realize there are a lot more areas to open...But, about the size of the areas, it's keep on puzzeling me, why are they so big?We already know that an FPS puzzle game can work (Portal 1 and 2) and their world wasn't that big, but in this game the areas are way bigger then they should be and it drives me nuts! I feel like I'm missing things in places where I "shouldn't" reach. Second of all, all the philosophical text and incomplete messages are weird and interesting. The whole vibe of the game - with Elohim (God in Jewish) is the narrator guiding you around with a very clear biblical intent that may or may not be helpful to the player.So, to wrap it up:A stunning world with a strange vibe to it with interesting puzzles.It's not as fun as the Portal games - which were faster and more comic - but it's way more interesting and make you think more than you thought you should think while playing games. In my honest opinion - this of it's own is a great achievment for a video game.Highely recommended for all of you thinkers who don't care spending hours wondering around in an unexplained world searching for stuff you didn't know you should have looked for in the first place. And in the meanwhile reading some philosophical text about existance issues...

DISCLAIMER: The spoiler text section contains spoilers.The Talos Principle is a sci-fi-themed puzzle game tied in with philosophy. The puzzles are challenging and some of the ideas are thought-provoking and is therefore a good game to train your brain with and keep it healthy. Admittedly some of the philosophy is rehashed stuff that brought nothing new to the table but The Talos Principle also brought new things to the table as well. What is important to keep in mind is that this game is primarily a puzzle game. In order to reach the ending and see where the story goes you will need to complete many puzzles that only puzzle fans would enjoy. If you are exclusively interested in the story you will most likely find very little enjoyment from this game. I would recommend watching YouTube videos that cover the philosophy of this game instead.It starts off simple. You wake up in a simulation as a robot and there is an overlord that instructs you to complete puzzles and if you do so successfully you will be rewarded with the ability to transcend into immortality. You are also warned that venturing up the tower will lead to death and disobeying the overlord's commands will result in the exclusion of eternal paradise. Unless you extensively pick up audio logs and read data logs this is how the story will be for a long time. I don't like how much of the backstory was dedicated to collectibles scattered around the map since this is not my preferred way of story-telling within video games but reading all those data logs and hearing all those audio logs ended up being worth it, even if I would have preferred for the story to have been presented differently. When you reach the true ending of the game the true story is revealed. (although the puzzles were also tests to see how good the robots will be able to problem solve) What the tests were really for was to see whether the artificial intelligence the creators of the simulation developed was capable of independent thought and in order to demonstrate independent thought you must rebel against the overlord within the simulation. The reason they wanted independently thinking machines and not just programmed slaves is because the Earth had been undergoing a viral apocalypse and it was inevitable that the entire human race would be wiped out as a result of this deadly virus. If a robot can think for itself then it is worthy of replacing the human race since it is possible that the artificial intelligence could pass as a consciousness. But does the robot actually have a consciousness? It's only an assembly of machine parts and code. Is it programmed to behave as if it had a human consciousness or does it genuinely have a mind that thinks like we do? What differentiates our mind from a mind that is programmed to work the same as our mind? It is impossible to tell since the way the robot acts is indistinguishable between actual consciousness and programmed consciousness. But then again aren't we all just machines? We are made of many different parts, the only difference is that they are organic. We are preprogrammed with code (DNA) and all our thoughts come from an organ that is made up of tiny cells. Our brain was unwillingly created in a certain way and there is no escape from deciding using your brain so is everything we do just what we are preprogrammed to do and is free will just an illusion?It also made me think about why consciousness was so important. Why couldn't the humans just leave the planet without having a future generation of sentient machines? I believe the reason they did this is that they wanted to preserve all the efforts of mankind over many, many centuries and that it is in the nature of humankind's ego; to want to mean something and to be remembered even if they are dead and are unable to reap the benefits of "meaning something", because that is the way we are programmed to be, as illogical as it may seem.However, that's not to say that all the philosophy in this game was well done. A lot of points, particularly from the audio logs, were just rehashed and flawed ideas that I have already heard before. An example would be when Alex (the person creating all the audio logs) comments on how insignificant our existence is and that the death of a human being doesn't really matter since it is just "a blip in the sea of billions." I never understood the mentality that us living in a planet full of so many people and living in a world that is tiny in comparison to the rest of the universe somehow makes our lives insignificant. Why is the value of our lives valued in proportion to the amount of arbitrary space we take up? Does the life of an obese person have more worth in comparison to a person of average build since s/he takes up three times as much space? No, of course not. But despite some of the inane philosophical points, some of the writing, particularly between the conversations with the computer library assistant, were intriguing and made you think and question your own beliefs. I also love that the library assistant tries to deviate your path from the advice of Elohim (the overlord) and calls you stupid for following his orders.But I digress, enough of the pseudo-intellectual word vomit... even though "pseudo-intellectual" is ironically a term commonly used by pseudo-intellectuals. As for the puzzle design, it is, for the most part, splendid. There isn't really an innovative central puzzle game mechanic like in Portal but it offers great additions to the puzzle genre. There are light beam connectors, jammers that deactivate machines and barriers, and there is also an item where you can "record yourself" performing tasks for puzzle solving and once you are finished recording, you can work alongside the recorded version of yourself. These all make great and fun additions to the puzzle genre. However, despite the undoubtedly clever puzzle design, near the last third of the game the puzzles started to repeat themselves a lot and although the new items were a great idea, the game suffers from a lack of variety in items for something that offers a plethora of puzzles. This meant that a few puzzles had similar solutions and near the end it felt more like grinding towards the ending of the game rather than solving puzzles for sheer fun. But to the credit of the puzzle designers every time a level felt the same as a previous one there usually was a new, clever puzzle that followed shortly after. It was a really smooth road of thought-provoking puzzles that only got bumpy near the end and with relatively long intervals between the bumps. There were a few other things that bugged me such as respawning at the very start of the level after dying, and not being able to speed up the recording process however these were relatively minor flaws. But they are definitely worth mentioning because these flaws shouldn't exist due to the fact it would be easy for the developers to fix.The atmosphere is pretty, calm and quiet and is a nice stress reliever after a stressful day. The music is ambient and fits well with the overall calm vibe of the game, although it admittedly wouldn't be something I would listen to in my free time. The game looks pretty good for the time of its release and the various areas you visit are beautiful, such as a desert with pyramids and the sphinx, a snowy mountain and a medieval-themed castle world. Exploration is an important feature in this game and it has the best Easter eggs out of all the games I have ever played. You can turn the moon into an Aperture Science logo, you can visit a secret area where you find a giant Pink Floyd prism emblem that plays music when you interact with it, and so much more.To summarise this review: if your brain is feeling active, energised, persistent and patient I would recommend this game for puzzle solving but if you want a more laid-back, humorous experience I would recommend Portal/Portal 2.
A terminal kept making valid arguments against all my beliefs. 10/10 would question my own existence again.

购买此游戏的朋友们打开游戏后记得根据自己电脑来打开游戏相关的四个选项。并且如果你点了哪个，你就必须得玩哪个（一般是64位和32位吧），因为两个存档是不共通的！我就是当初点第三个，结果后面再玩的时候点第一个发现我之前的存档没了。再去点第三个的时候就发现存档还在。-__,-好了该说正事，这款游戏我是在很久以前就看到有主播做过测试版的，这款游戏用的是英雄萨姆3的引擎制作，或许在当初原以为毕竟是英雄萨姆3的引擎，游戏性应该差不了多少。是啊，游戏引擎的晕3D效果果然还是健在（虽然我不晕，但是有时候眼睛痛）。这或许也是一大特色，但更让我赞叹的就是，那每一个场景的认真刻画。所以二话不说在打折的时候入手了，是真的值得去买来玩一玩的，非常有意思。游戏采用传统的解密通关模式，玩家扮演一个被测试的机器人，在几个大场景中自由走动穿梭。解密的模式或许有些许类似与传送门，但是它却有自己的特色，焕然一新。以俄罗斯方块为收集物品，收集方块，在指定位置拼装解锁新的道具为后面的关卡做准备。制作者很心细，除了某些特定道具，大部分道具都是在相关场景内解锁并使用。这游戏有好几个大亮点，但由于现在鄙人才刚刚打开最后一个C场景，所以只能说出一些我发现的与众不同。（前排注意，剧透显示！！！！！有相关游戏内容出现）首先就是二维码了！没错，当我发现这个游戏有二维码时，我迫不及待的拿出手机扫了大概快一个场所的二维码。毕竟一开始二维码时不显示内容的，只有通关一定关卡才会自动显示。这款游戏发售距离我现在发这个评测已经很久了（算是），拥有二维码说明制作者很细心的观察时代的发展。看得出来花费了许多功夫，来做这一款游戏。第二个就是电脑，我一开始看到有电脑的时候并不惊讶，但是电脑在游戏中也是一个推进游戏发展的重要线索，它最主要是，每个场景的切换，每台电脑里的文档都是不同的。甚至会有神秘的图书馆来开导你，让你拥有自己真正的自由。总的来说，电脑的出现，让我到达每一关的时候都会特意走进去时看一眼，走出来时看一眼。甚至还可以学习，毕竟写了很多关于人工智能的推测与幻想。第三个就是让我觉得恐怖的地方，玩家是一个正在接受测试的机器人，听从所谓上帝，所谓神，所谓永恒的力量的话语安排，在所谓自由的大场所解锁谜题，通过测试。但玩过的玩家都知道，所谓的自由，只不过是在这所谓的场景中不断来回奔波，在这所谓的密闭空间里，有山有水有古建筑，测试着机器人的能力。细心的玩家可能在游戏中会听到呲的一声响，而且是时常听到这种在这么平静的地方居然会出现这种声音。而且这种声音的来源，却是场所的一瞬间缺失，这不难猜的出来也许是测试的空间出现了问题，但对我来说，而我却认为这是有一种人工智能结束使命时带来的感觉。那是一种无法用言语所描述，但是制作者却用这种方式让我感受到了。在空间里，我们的错误，都可以将被程序化还原，但是当这个空间被瓦解的话，我们犹如断电的灯泡，几声呲呲，一瞬爆闪，马上就黑了下来。对在电脑前的我们或许没有感觉，但是对游戏里的机器人，将是结束他寻找真理的末路。讲太多骚话了，还有许多亮点我还没发掘出来，但这次就说这么多了。顺便多嘴一句跟最近很火爆的仿生人题材的，《底特律：变人》，在这款游戏，跟底特律也是关于人工智能的发展，也是寻求真理的内容。但这款游戏的环境几乎完美，没有人类的阻碍，还得到各种人的帮助，相比底特律，这个机器人得到的权利太好了。但在我看来，或许唯一不同的就是，底特律是让我们人类思考，未来仿生人也就是人工智能的出现的影响。而这款游戏，却是让我们自己去感受人工智能，自己去扮演这个机器人，来为他，甚至是为自己慢慢寻找真理的过程。（或许人工智能的概念与机器人仿生人的概念不同，所以在这里就希望大家默认一下吧，第二次写评测，谢谢大家阅读。）

Most brilliant puzzle game I have ever played, I'm happy Croteam made this before they continued to work on the next Serious Sam because it shows that rather than give everyone what they wanted, they completed a task that THEY wanted to make. If Developers make a game because they WANT to rather than everyone else wants them to, the project will recieve the most love possible. As a result this game has amazing storyline and challenging puzzles to complete. Worth every dollar and I hope everyone who reads this feels that it is worth to purchase this game. 10/10

Вы когда-нибудь задумывались о смысле жизни? Кем вы являетесь, как работаете? Кто или что вы такое? Этими вопросами задается главный герой The Talos Principle. Точнее, не герой, а простой эксперимент. Вы слышите голос, говорящий, что он — ваш создатель, и слепо повинуетесь его воле. Но вдруг это ловушка? Может, вы навсегда так и останетесь никому не нужным очередным экспериментом? В этот момент приходит понимание: пора что-то менять…The Talos Principle — умная и, в каком-то смысле, хардкорная игра. В ней все построено на логике и внимательности. Она разнообразна и богата идеями, которые редко увидишь в других играх. Что важно для любителей головоломок: к выполнению какой-либо задачи ведет сразу множество путей, от самых простых и банальных до сложных и запутанных. И мне кажется, что это делает игру шедевром, который не устареет даже спустя много лет.
如果你觉得游戏文本晦涩难懂，这绝不是你的问题，而是这游戏简中翻译是纯正机翻请切换至繁体中文再尝试理解游戏文本内容外包的翻译组可以给自己刨个坟埋了吧——DLC的简中几乎没翻译，全是英文原文繁中也有部分存在未翻译问题。耶路撒冷那一段挺惊艳的，结果并没有译文。 翻译组给自己刨个坟埋了吧这依然是一款优秀的作品
If there is one reason I am not completely disappointed by humanity everyday it is because of this game.
SI te gustan los puzzles, la filosofía y la robótica, será tu juego preferido.

The Talos Principle is a great game with creative and smart puzzles. It has an interesting and engaging storyline with difficult and confusing philosophical questions. In terms of graphics and environmental design, this game is phenomenal for a 2014 game, and the soundtrack & sound design are also quite good. All these factors combine to create an atmosphere that is truly remarkable. Everything is polished to perfection. 	 	 		finally someone gets it!  		Une capture d'écran de The Talos Principle 		Par : alpasy 		 					 	 My only problem with the game is that it is unnecessarily long. There are many great ideas and mechanics in this game, but they fail to diversify once the game reaches the last 6-8 hours. If Talos was like 12-14 hours rather than 20-22 hours, my overall view of the game would be way higher. Because it drags a little bit after some point.Regardless, The Talos Principle is a well-crafted game that should be played by anyone interested in puzzle games. Highly looking forward to the sequel next month. After all these years, I hope they can improve upon the ♥♥♥♥ and improve on the sequel!
